body_text.text: Cytoplasmic dynein is a 1.2-MD multisubunit motor complex that powers movement of various cargoes toward the minus ends of microtubules.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This ancient and highly conserved ATPase organizes the intracellular environment throughout the cell cycle; however, its myriad roles become especially apparent during mitosis when it functions in various aspects of spindle morphogenesis and positioning (Rusan et al., 2002;Goshima et al., 2005;Yang et al., 2007;Ferenz et al., 2009;Siller and Doe, 2009).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For instance, cortically anchored dynein motors position the spindle at the future site of cytokinesis (Eshel et al., 1993;Li et al., 1993;Carminati and Stearns, 1997), a process that is particularly important during asymmetric cell divisions, when spindle position dictates the plane of cell division, and thus cell fate determination (Pease and Tirnauer, 2011;Williams et al., 2011).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The means by which dynein is delivered to the cell cortex and subsequently activated to pull on astral microtubules emanating from spindle poles to move the spindle are unclear.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Recent studies in budding and fission yeast have revealed two distinct mechanisms by which dynein can be targeted to the cell cortex, its site of action in both organisms Ananthanarayanan et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: During the meiotic prophase in fission yeast, studies suggest that dynein first binds along astral microtubules that are in close proximity to the cell cortex (Ananthanarayanan et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Rather than walking toward the minus end of these microtubules, dynein undergoes one-dimensional diffusion until it encounters Mcp5, its cortical anchor.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Once bound to Mcp5, dynein mo-tors switch from diffusive to directed motion and consequently move the spindle appropriately.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Thus, in addition to anchoring dynein at the cortex, Mcp5 appears to activate dynein motility by an unknown mechanism.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A similar but somewhat distinct scenario takes place in budding yeast, in which dynein is first targeted to the plus ends of astral microtubules before being offloaded to cortical Num1 (Mcp5 homologue) receptor sites, where it functions to move the mitotic spindle toward the daughter cell (Adames and Cooper, 2000;Lee et al., 2005;.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is unknown if dynein motility is activated subsequent to offloading; however, several lines of evidence suggest that its activity is switched from being off at plus ends to being on at the cell cortex.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For instance, in spite of its minus end-directed motility, dynein is transported to, and remains associated with, the plus ends of dynamic microtubules (Lee et al., 2003;Carvalho et al., 2004).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Plus end targeting requires the dynein motor domain, the +TIP (plus end-tracking protein) Bik1 (CLIP-170 homologue), and the dynein-associated factor Pac1 (homologue of human LIS1; Lee et al., 2003;Sheeman et al., 2003;Markus et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Recent studies suggest that Pac1 plays two distinct and important roles in targeting dynein to plus ends.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: First, Pac1 mediates the interaction between dynein and plus end-bound Bik1 (Sheeman et al., 2003;Roberts et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Second, by inhibiting dynein motility Huang et al., 2012), and/or by prolonging its microtubule attachment (Yamada et al., 2008; Cortically anchored dynein orients the spindle through interactions with astral microtubules.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In budding yeast, dynein is offloaded to Num1 receptors from microtubule plus ends.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Rather than walking toward minus ends, dynein remains associated with plus ends due in part to its association with Pac1/LIS1, an inhibitor of dynein motility.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The mechanism by which dynein is switched from "off" at the plus ends to "on" at the cell cortex remains unknown.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Here, we show that overexpression of the coiled-coil domain of Num1 specifically depletes dynein-dynactin-Pac1/LIS1 complexes from microtubule plus ends and reduces dynein-Pac1/LIS1 colocalization.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Depletion of dynein from plus ends requires its microtubule-binding domain, suggesting that motility is required.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An enhanced Pac1/LIS1 affinity mutant of dynein or overexpression of Pac1/LIS1 rescues dynein plus end depletion.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Live-cell imaging reveals minus end-directed dyneindynactin motility along microtubules upon overexpression of the coiled-coil domain of Num1, an event that is not observed in wild-type cells.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Our findings indicate that dynein activity is directly switched "on" by Num1, which induces Pac1/LIS1 removal.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The dynein cortical anchor Num1 activates dynein motility by relieving Pac1/LIS1-mediated inhibition McKenney et al., 2010;Huang et al., 2012), Pac1 holds dynein at plus ends by keeping dynein in a nonmotile, or "off" state.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Thus, plus end-associated dynein may be poised to walk toward the minus ends of microtubules but is prevented from doing so by Pac1.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, upon offloading to cortical Num1 receptor sites, dynein is active, as apparent by its capacity to pull on astral microtubules and consequently move the spindle.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Thus, in budding yeast, as in fission yeast, dynein may undergo a switch in its activity upon attachment to its cortical receptor.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, evidence for such a switch is lacking.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Although factors have been identified that can inhibit dynein motility (e.g., MAP4, She1, and Pac1; Samora et al., 2011;Huang et al., 2012;Markus et al., 2012), it remains unclear whether dynein from organisms other than fission yeast need to be switched on to perform their cellular functions or whether they are constitutively active.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Recent studies indicated that purified metazoan dynein is functional for motility in ensemble assays (e.g., microtubule gliding) but requires a stable interaction with the dynactin complex for single-molecule processivity (McKenney et al., 2014;Schlager et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Stabilization of the dynein-dynactin interaction by various coiled-coil-containing adaptor proteins (e.g., BicD2, Spindly, Hook3, and Rab11-Fip3) is sufficient to significantly enhance dynein processivity, and thereby "activate" dynein motility.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This is in contrast to budding yeast dynein, which is processive in the absence of dynactin or other adaptors or regulators (Reck-Peterson et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is unclear whether such a mechanism generally governs dynein regulation within a cell, given that certain functions of dynein in animal cells, such as centrosome anchoring, pole focusing, and spindle length regulation, have been shown to occur independently of several such adaptors (Raaijmakers et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is also unclear whether dynactin-mediated processivity enhancement is the means by which cortical dynein activity is promoted.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Interestingly, plus end association of dynein in higher eukaryotes, which occurs in a dynactin-dependent manner, does not require such adaptor proteins (Splinter et al., 2012;Duellberg et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Given the lack of minus end-directed motility of these plus endassociated dynein motors, an interaction between dynein and dynactin is not necessarily sufficient to active dynein motility.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Using budding yeast, we aimed to test the hypothesis that binding of dynein-dynactin to its cortical receptor provides the switch that activates cortical dynein activity.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Dynein pathway function is best understood in this genetically tractable organism, in which many of the regulatory components and accessory chains, which are each encoded by only one gene, are highly conserved.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We found that overexpression of the dynein-dynactininteracting coiled-coil domain of Num1 (Num1 CC ) is sufficient to activate dynein motility, causing a depletion of dynein-dynactin from microtubule plus ends, their accumulation at minus ends, and their apparent minus end-directed motility along astral microtubules.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Our data reveal that the mechanism for this activation is likely a Num1 CC -mediated release of Pac1, a potent dynein inhibitor, from the dynein motor domain.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A recent study revealed that the N-terminal coiled-coil domain of Num1-the dynein cortical receptor-directly interacts with dynein-dynactin complexes (Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: If this region of Num1 (Num1 CC ; Fig. 1 A) is sufficient to activate dynein motility, we reasoned that its overexpression would result in
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: (a) the depletion of dynein and dynactin from microtubule plus ends, and
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: (b) an accumulation of dynein-dynactin at spindle pole bodies (SPBs), where microtubule minus ends are anchored ( Fig. 1 B).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We found this latter phenomenon to be an inherent property of dynein motility, because single-molecule motility experiments demonstrated that upon reaching the end of a microtubule, dynein pauses for several seconds before detaching, much longer than the dwell time of ∼0.1 s per step ( Fig. S1 and Video 1).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: To test our hypothesis, we engineered yeast cells such that the galactose-inducible GAL1 promoter (GAL1p) was immediately upstream of a truncated num1 CC allele (Fig. 1 C).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Because Num1 CC is expressed from the native NUM1 locus, these cells do not possess a full-length Num1.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Consequently, dynein and dynactin are excluded from the cell cortex and are unable to properly orient the spindle in these cells.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: In the absence of Num1 CC induction (by growth in glucose-containing media), we observed fluorescent foci of functional Dyn1-(dynein heavy chain) and Jnm1-3mCherry (p50 subunit of dynactin) fusions  at microtubule plus ends in 77.2% and 41.4% of cells, respectively (Fig. 1,D and E).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: In contrast, upon induction of Num1 CC overexpression (by growth in galactose-containing media), the number of cells exhibiting Dyn1-and Jnm1-3mCherry plus end foci was reduced by approximately fivefold, to 14.8% and 8.1%, respectively.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Fluorescence intensity measurements revealed that those plus ends with Dyn1-and Jnm1-3mCherry foci had significantly fewer molecules of each upon Num1 CC overexpression ( Fig. 1 F).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Coincident with the reduction in plus end dynein and dynactin, we also observed a four-to fivefold increase in the number of cells with Dyn1-and Jnm1-3mCherry foci at SPBs upon Num1 CC induction (also see Fig. 4 A, bottom).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We observed similar results for Pac11-(dynein intermediate chain) and Dyn3-3mCherry (dynein light-intermediate chain; Fig. S2, A-E).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: In contrast, overexpression of Num1 CC had no effect on the extent of plus end localization of Bik1-3mCherry (CLIP170 homologue), a protein that is required for the plus end targeting of dynein (Fig. S2, F and G;Sheeman et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: To determine whether there is a cell cycle-regulated component to Num1 CC -mediated dynein relocalization, we categorized plus end and SPB localization frequencies into the following: G1, preanaphase, and anaphase (as determined by cell and spindle morphology; see Fig. S2 H).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Although both G1 and preanaphase cells exhibited an equivalent extent of Num1 CC -mediated dynein relocalization, we found that anaphase cells were less susceptible to dynein plus end depletion, in spite of a significant enhancement in the prevalence of SPB localized dynein in these cells ( Fig. S2 H).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: These findings are consistent with the higher frequency of dynein plus end localization noted in wild-type anaphase cells (Sheeman et al., 2003;Markus et al., 2009), and they further suggest that the plus end targeting mechanism is more robust at this point of the cell cycle.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Collectively, our data indicate that overexpression of Num1 CC specifically depletes dynein-dynactin from microtubule plus ends.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We next wanted to determine whether a Num1-dynein interaction was required for the plus end depletion phenotype.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: First, we introduced two point mutations within Num1 CC (L167E L170E; Num1 CC LL/EE ; Fig. 2 A) that disrupt its interaction with dynein-dynactin but have no effect on Num1 localization or its mitochondria cortical attachment function (Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We found that overexpression of Num1 CC LL/EE (Fig. 1 C) had no effect on dynein plus end or SPB localization (Fig. 2, B and C), indicating that an intact dynein-dynactin binding surface within Num1 CC is required for plus end depletion.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Second, we used two dynein motor domain variants (Dyn1 MOT OR and GST-Dyn1 MOT OR ) that are sufficient for association with microtubule plus ends but lack the N-terminal tail domain that is required for association with Num1 (Fig. 2 D ;Markus et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We found that Num1 CC overexpression had little effect on the frequency by which monomeric (nonmotile) Dyn1 MOT OR -3YFP or the dimeric (motile; Reck-Peterson et al., 2006) GST-Dyn1 MOT OR -3mCherry fragment was observed at plus ends or SPBs (Fig. 2, E and F).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Collectively, these data indicate that Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein requires an interaction between dynein and Num1 CC .
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Several lines of evidence indicate that an intact dyneindynactin complex is required for interaction with Num1.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Yeast dynactin deletion mutants exhibit a complete loss of cortical dynein and a higher than normal accumulation of dynein at microtubule plus ends (Lee et al., 2003(Lee et al., , 2005.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: This latter observation is also noted in num1Δ mutants (Lee et al., 2003) and is presumed to be attributable to an inability to offload dynein-dynactin to cortical Num1 receptor sites.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: Finally, a bead-immobilized recombinant Num1 CC fragment was sufficient to isolate dynein from cell extracts but was unable to do so from extracts prepared from nip100Δ cells (homologue of human dynactin component p150Glued; Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: To determine whether Num1 CC can deplete plus end dynein in the absence of dynactin, we overexpressed Num1 CC in nip100Δ Figure 1.

body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We found that Num1 CC overexpression reduced the frequency of dynein plus end localization in nip100Δ cells to a lesser extent than in NIP100 cells (Fig. S3, A and B; 38% reduction in nip100Δ vs. 81% reduction in NIP100 cells; compare with Fig. 1 E); however, fluorescence intensity measurements of plus end dynein revealed no significant difference ( Fig. S3 C).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: These data suggest that the ability of dynein to interact with Num1 CC is compromised but not abolished in the absence of dynactin.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: We next asked whether plus end targeting of dynein is a requisite for Num1 CC -mediated accumulation of dynein at SPBs.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: To test this, we deleted either Pac1 or Bik1, both of which are required for dynein plus end targeting (Lee et al., 2003;Sheeman et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: As expected, neither pac1Δ nor bik1Δ cells overexpressing Num1 CC exhibited plus end dynein foci; in addition, SPB localization of dynein was apparent in only a small number of cells in both mu-tants, suggesting that the accumulation of dynein at SPBs requires a pool of dynein-dynactin at plus ends from which to draw (Fig. S3, D-G).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dyneindynactin from microtubule plus ends

body_text.text: If Num1 CC -mediated redistribution of dynein from plus ends to SPBs is a consequence of activated dynein motility, then we reasoned that a motility-incompetent dynein mutant would remain associated with plus ends in the presence of overexpressed Num1 CC .
body_text.section: Microtubule binding by dynein is required for plus end depletion

body_text.text: To test this, we generated a dynein mutant lacking its microtubule-binding domain (MTBD; Dyn1 ΔMT BD ; Fig. 3 A).
body_text.section: Microtubule binding by dynein is required for plus end depletion

body_text.text: Surprisingly, we found that in the absence of Num1 CC induction, Dyn1 ΔMT BD was capable of plus end binding (Fig. 3, B and C, top in B), indicating that dynein associates with plus ends independently of its MTBD, and thus likely through its interaction with Pac1 and Bik1.
body_text.section: Microtubule binding by dynein is required for plus end depletion

body_text.text: Furthermore, we found that the Interaction between dynein and Num1 CC is required for plus end depletion.

body_text.section: Microtubule binding by dynein is required for plus end depletion

body_text.text: These data suggest that SPB localization of dynein in wild-type cells may be attributable to minus end-directed motility of active dynein motors.
body_text.section: Microtubule binding by dynein is required for plus end depletion

body_text.text: Consistent with our hypothesis, upon induction of Num1 CC overexpression, Dyn1 ΔMT BD localization to plus ends and SPBs remained unchanged (Fig. 3, C and D), suggesting that Num1 CC -mediated depletion of dynein from plus ends and accumulation at SPBs both require dynein motility.
body_text.section: Microtubule binding by dynein is required for plus end depletion

body_text.text: In contrast to yeast dynein, metazoan dynein exhibits mostly nonprocessive, diffusive motility in single-molecule assays (Miura et al., 2010;McKenney et al., 2014;Schlager et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: A family of coiled-coil-containing adaptor proteins that recruit dynein and dynactin to various cellular sites was recently shown to be sufficient to activate processive single-molecule motility by stably linking dynein to dynactin (McKenney et al., 2014;Schlager et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: Like these adaptor proteins, Num1 interacts only with intact dynein-dynactin complexes Figure 3.

body_text.text: through its coiled-coil domain (Splinter et al., 2012;Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: Although dynein recruits dynactin to plus ends in a Num1-independent manner, dynactin is present at substoichiometric amounts relative to dynein (approximately three dynein to one dynactin; .
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: Thus, we reasoned that Num1 CC may activate dynein motility by enhancing the dyneindynactin interaction at plus ends.
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: To test this, we assessed the extent by which Num1 CC affects dynein-mediated recruitment of dynactin to plus ends.
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: For these experiments, we used dyn1 ΔMT BD mutant cells, in which dynein remains associated at plus ends in spite of Num1 CC overexpression (see Fig. 3, B-D).
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: We found that Num1 CC overexpression had no effect on the frequency of observing plus end-localized dynactin (i.e., Jnm1or Nip100-3mCherry; Fig. 3, E-G); however, the fluorescence intensities of both Jnm1 and Nip100 at plus ends were modestly, but significantly, increased (Fig. 3 H; 58.9% and 30.9%, respectively; P ≤ 0.0012), suggesting that Num1 CC may in fact enhance or stabilize the dynein-dynactin interaction.
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: However, given the small apparent change in dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends, and the observation that yeast dynein processivity enhancement by dynactin does not require additional factors in vitro (i.e., Num1; Kardon et al., 2009), it is unclear whether stabilization of the dynein-dynactin interaction is the mechanism by which Num1 functions to activate dynein motility.
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: For these reasons, we explored an alternative hypothesis.
body_text.section: Num1 CC has only a modest effect on dynein-dynactin interaction at plus ends

body_text.text: Cells in which Pac1 is deleted exhibit a complete loss of plus end dynein (Lee et al., 2003;Markus et al., 2009), similar to our observations of cells overexpressing Num1 CC .
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: We hypothesized that Num1 CC may deplete dynein from plus ends by interfering with dynein-Pac1 binding.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: To test this, we assessed localization of a functional Pac1-3mCherry fusion  in cells overexpressing Num1 CC .
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: As we observed for dynein and dynactin, Pac1-3mCherry foci were depleted from microtubule plus ends upon Num1 CC overexpression (Fig. 4, A and B), consistent with their codependence for plus end targeting .
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: However, in contrast to dynein and dynactin, the fraction of cells exhibiting Pac1-3mCherry foci at SPBs was reduced with respect to cells not expressing Num1 CC , suggesting that dynein localizes at SPBs without Pac1 upon Num1 CC overexpression.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: This reduction in localization was not due to a decrease in Pac1 protein expression or stability, as indicated by immunoblotting ( Fig. 4 D).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: Consistent with a Num1 CC -mediated reduction in the dynein-Pac1 interaction, we found that the fraction of Dyn1-3YFP and Pac1-3mCherry foci that colocalized (either SPB or plus end) was reduced upon induction of Num1 CC (from 59.6% to 26.2%; Fig. 4 E), whereas the fraction of Dyn1-3YFP foci alone (i.e., not colocalized with Pac1) increased (from 28.3% to 62.3%).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: These data suggest that overexpression of Num1 CC may disrupt plus end binding of dynein-dynactin by interfering with the dynein-Pac1 interaction.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: We next wanted to determine whether the reduction in Pac1-dynein colocalization was a direct consequence of Num1 CC -mediated Pac1-dynein dissociation, or whether it was a secondary consequence of dynein plus end depletion.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: To distinguish between these two possibilities, we ectopically targeted dynein to the plasma membrane using an exogenous pleckstrin homology (PH) domain, and we assessed the degree of colocalization of Pac1 with cortical PH-Dyn1 in the presence of either Num1 CC LL/EE or Num1 CC .
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: We found that the PH domain was sufficient to target dynein ( Fig. 4 F and Fig. S4 A) and dynactin (i.e., Jnm1; Fig. S4 B) to the cell cortex in cells lacking cortical Num1.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

ref_spans.text: Fig. 4 F and Fig. S4 A)

body_text.text: Interestingly, we found a greater frequency of cortical PH-Dyn1-3mCherry foci in Num1 CC -overexpressing cells than in either Num1 CC LL/EE -overexpressing cells (45.5% vs. 13.9%, respectively) or NUM1 cells (21.3%; not depicted).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: In addition, we noted that Num1 CC -overexpressing cells exhibited larger cortical patches than either wild-type NUM1 or Num1 CC LL/EEoverexpressing cells (Fig. S4 A; data not depicted).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: These data suggest that PH-Dyn1-Num1 CC complexes may be oligomerizing at the cell cortex, which is consistent with the previously described role for the Num1 CC domain in the assembly of higher-order cortical patches (Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: In cells overexpressing Num1 CC LL/EE , Pac1-3YFP colocalized with 65.3% of cortical PH-Dyn1-3mCherry foci; however, upon overexpression of Num1 CC , only 29.1% of PH-Dyn1-3mCherry foci contained Pac1-3YFP fluorescence (Fig. 4 G).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: Fluorescence intensity measurements also revealed a significant reduction in the number of Pac1 molecules associated with cortical PH-dynein patches (Fig. 4 H).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: In contrast, we noted no significant change in either the frequency or intensity of colocalized dynactin (i.e., Jnm1; Fig. 4, I and J; and Fig. S4 B).
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: These data support the notion that Num1 CC disrupts the dynein-Pac1 interaction, thereby leading to the plus end depletion phenotype.
body_text.section: Overexpression of Num1 CC reduces colocalization of dynein and Pac1

body_text.text: If a Num1 CC -mediated Pac1 unbinding event is the cause for plus end depletion of dynein-dynactin complexes, we reasoned that we could reduce the extent of Num1 CC -mediated dynein depletion from microtubule plus ends by two different means:
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: (a) enhancing the affinity of dynein for Pac1, or
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: (b) overexpression of Pac1.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: To test the former, we used a yeast strain expressing a well-characterized, motility-competent dynein mutant (Dyn1 HL3 ) that exhibits higher affinity for Pac1 than wild-type dynein (Fig. 5 A; Markus and Lee, 2011).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: We predicted that Dyn1 HL3 and Pac1 would be less susceptible to Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion as a result of their higher affinity.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Consistent with our hypothesis, induction of Num1 CC overexpression reduced the frequency of observing Dyn1 HL3 -3YFP and Pac1-3mCherry plus end foci by 40% and 22%, respectively (Fig. 5, B and C), much less than what we observed in wild-type DYN1 cells (respective 81% and 67% reduction; compare with Fig. 1 E and  Fig. 4 B).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Fluorescence intensity measurements revealed no significant change in the number of Dyn1 HL3 or Pac1 molecules at plus ends upon Num1 CC overexpression (Fig. 5 D).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Thus, both Pac1 and Dyn1 HL3 are less susceptible to plus end depletion by Num1 CC overexpression in dyn1 HL3 cells.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: To test whether overexpression of Pac1 could rescue plus end depletion, we replaced the native PAC1 promoter with the GAL1 promoter, which is sufficient to induce >10-fold higher Pac1 expression levels compared with wild-type cells .
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: To establish a baseline for Pac1 overexpressionmediated enhancement of dynein plus end targeting, we first assessed dynein localization in cells overexpressing Pac1 and Num1 CC LL/EE , the latter of which has no discernible effect on dynein targeting (see Fig. 2, B and C).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: In these cells, we observed an increase in both frequency and mean fluorescence intensity of plus end dynein by 44% and 170%, respectively (Fig. 6, B and D), compared with cells overexpressing Num1 CC LL/EE and expressing native levels of Pac1.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: In comparison, overexpression of Pac1 and wild-type Num1 CC reduced the frequency of plus end dynein by 47% (P < 0.0001; compare GAL1p:PAC1 with GAL1p:PAC1 num1 CC ), whereas the mean fluorescence intensity was not reduced significantly (30%; P = 0.1636; Fig. 6, B and D).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: These values are significantly less than the respective 78% and 37% reduction in frequency and intensity we observed when Num1 CC alone was overexpressed (compared with Num1 CC LL/EE ; Fig. 6, C and E).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Thus, Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent by which Num1 CC depletes dynein from microtubule plus ends.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: If Num1 CC depletes dynein from plus ends by inducing Pac1 release, then we reasoned that enhancing dynein plus end targeting by a Pac1-independent means would not be able to rescue plus end depletion to the same extent as Pac1 overexpression.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: To test this, we overexpressed Kip2, a kinesin-7 family member that affects steady-state microtubule length (see Fig. 6 A, bottom) and plays a role in transporting dynein to microtubule plus ends (Carvalho et al., 2004;Markus et al., 2009;Roberts et al., 2014).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: As with Pac1, we first established a baseline by which Kip2 overexpression enhances dynein plus end localization by imaging Dyn1-3mCherry in GAL1p:KIP2 GAL1p:num1 CC LL/EE cells.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Consistent with a role for Kip2 in transporting dynein away from minus ends and toward plus ends, overexpression of Kip2 enhanced the frequency of dynein plus end targeting by 19% and reduced the frequency of SPB targeting by 83% (P = 0.0019; Fig. 6 B).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Fluorescence intensity measurements revealed a robust 147% increase in the number of dynein molecules per plus end (Fig. 6 D).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: When both Kip2 and wild-type Num1 CC were overexpressed, the frequency and mean fluorescence intensity of plus end dynein was reduced by 59% (P < 0.0001) and 63% (P = 0.0012), respectively, compared with GAL1p:KIP2 GAL1p:num1 CC LL/EE cells (Fig. 6, B-E).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: The extent by which Kip2 overexpression reduces Num1 CCmediated plus end dynein depletion is therefore less than that of Pac1.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Collectively, these data are consistent with our hypothesis, and they suggest that Num1 CC and Pac1 are competing for binding to dynein-dynactin complexes.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: It is interesting to note that Pac1 binds to dynein within the C-terminal motor domain (Reck-Peterson et al., 2006;Markus et al., 2009;Huang et al., 2012;Toropova et al., 2014), whereas Num1 associates with dynein via the N-terminal tail domain (Markus et al., 2009).
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Thus, interference with Dyn1-Pac1 binding by Num1 CC likely occurs by an allosteric mechanism.
body_text.section: An enhanced Pac1 affinity mutant of dynein or Pac1 overexpression reduces the extent of Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion of dynein

body_text.text: Previous data indicate that Num1 CC interacts with dynein at SPBs and is found in the cytoplasm as bright foci (presumably aggregates; see Fig. S5, A and B, open arrows and cytoplasm, respectively; Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Num1 CC colocalizes with dynein-dynactin

body_text.text: We found that localization of Num1 CC to the SPB is largely dependent on dynein, and more specifically, the MTBD of dynein (Fig. S5, A and B).
body_text.section: Num1 CC colocalizes with dynein-dynactin

body_text.text: Furthermore, cells in which dynein plus end targeting is restored-by overexpression of Pac1, deletion of the dynein MTBD, or use of Dyn1 HL3 -exhibit Num1 CC at plus ends, albeit at a low frequency (Fig. S5, A-C).
body_text.section: Num1 CC colocalizes with dynein-dynactin

body_text.text: These data indicate that Num1 CC can bind plus end dynein (as well as the Dyn1 ΔMT BD and Dyn1 HL3 mutants) and suggest that Num1 and Pac1 binding to dynein is not entirely mutually exclusive.
body_text.section: Num1 CC colocalizes with dynein-dynactin

body_text.text: The latter is consistent with the observation that Dyn1 HL3 -Pac1 complexes can offload together to Num1 cortical sites .
body_text.section: Num1 CC colocalizes with dynein-dynactin

body_text.text: In budding yeast, dynein is targeted to microtubule plus ends by two distinct mechanisms:
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: (a) direct recruitment from the cytoplasm, and
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: (b) Kip2-mediated plus end-directed transport along astral microtubules (Carvalho et al., 2004;Markus et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Evidence of the latter is apparent by the movement of fluorescent dynein speckles along astral microtubules toward plus ends ( Fig. 7 A and Video 2; Markus et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: In budding yeast, dynein is never observed moving in the opposite direction-toward the minus ends of astral microtubules.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Minus end-directed activity is only apparent when cortically anchored dynein motors move the spindle through interactions with astral microtubules.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: If depletion of dynein-dynactin from microtubule plus ends is a consequence of these motors being switched "on," then we reasoned that cells overexpressing Num1 CC would exhibit dynein molecules moving in a directed manner toward the minus ends of astral microtubules, as was recently observed in fission yeast expressing a Mcp5 ΔPH (Num1 homologue) fragment (Ananthanarayanan et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: In uninduced cells (i.e., not expressing any Num1 CC ) or in those induced to express Num1 CC LL/EE , only plus enddirected motility of dynein (or dynein ΔMT BD ) molecules was ever observed (Fig. 7 A and Video 2).
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: We were unable to observe minus end-directed motility of dynein molecules Figure 5.

body_text.text: in cells overexpressing Num1 CC , likely because of the robust depletion of dynein from microtubule plus ends in these cells.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Thus, we chose to focus on cells in which Num1 CCmediated depletion of dynein plus end binding was partially restored: GAL1p:KIP2 and GAL1p:PAC1 cells.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Strikingly, we observed numerous instances of minus end-directed motility of dynein in cells overexpressing Kip2 or Pac1 in addition to Num1 CC (Fig. 7, B and C; Fig. S5 D; Video 3; and Video 4).
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

ref_spans.text: (Fig. 7, B and C; Fig. S5 D; Video 3;

body_text.text: The mean velocity of minus end-directed dynein molecules along astral microtubules in GAL1p:KIP2 cells was slightly higher than that in GAL1p:PAC1 cells (55.3 nm/s, n = 22; vs. 41.7 nm/s, n = 9; Fig. 7 D); however, the values from both strains were very similar to the velocity of single molecules of purified dynein (∼70-100 nm/s; Reck-Peterson et al., 2006;Huang et al., 2012) and dynein-mediated spindle movements in this organism (41 nm/s; .
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Thus, overexpression of Num1 CC depletes dynein from microtubule plus ends by activating its minus end-directed motility.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Although we were able to see Num1 CC -mediated minus end motility of dynactin (Jnm1-3YFP) in GAL1p:KIP2 cells ( Fig. 7 B, iii), we were unable to observe examples of either Pac1 or Num1 CC moving toward the minus ends.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: The reason for the latter is unclear but may be a result of disengagement of Num1 CC from dynein subsequent to activation.
body_text.section: Direct observation of minus end-directed motion of dynein along astral microtubules

body_text.text: Taken together with our other observations (i.e., the lack of Pac1 accumulation at SPBs in Num1 CC -overexpressing cells, the reduced colocalization of Dyn1 and Pac1 in DYN1 and PH-DYN1 cells, and the ability of Pac1 overexpression to rescue Dyn1 plus end targeting), the apparent lack of minus end-directed Pac1 molecules further suggests that Num1 CC activates plus end dynein by relieving Pac1-mediated inhibition.

body_text.text: When purified from various sources, including budding yeast and animal tissue, dynein motors are active as apparent from ATPase and microtubule gliding assays.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Yeast dynein requires no additional factors for processive single-molecule motility (Reck-Peterson et al., 2006), whereas dynein isolated from animal tissue requires a combination of dynactin and various adaptor proteins that link dynein to dynactin (McKenney et al., 2014;Schlager et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This latter phenomenon helps explain how dynein activity is recruited to different vesicular or organellar compartments in animal cells, and thus how dynein activity is regulated with spatial precision.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: For instance, one of these adaptors, BicD2, binds to Rab6 on various vesicular cargoes, and thereby recruits dynein-dynactin complexes, which allows for minus end-directed movements of these vesicular cargoes (Matanis et al., 2002).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Although mechanistically distinct, we have identified a similar mechanism at play in budding yeast.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Specifically, Num1-mediated recruitment of dynein-dynactin complexes to the cell cortex is sufficient to
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: (a) anchor dynein-dynactin complexes at their site of activity, and
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: (b) activate dynein for its spindle orientation function.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Unlike animal cells, however, association with dynactin is not sufficient to activate dynein motility in yeast cells.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Rather, our studies indicate that a Num1-mediated Pac1 dissociation event is responsible for switching dynein from being off at microtubule plus ends to on at the cell cortex.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our results revealed a small but significant Num1 CCmediated enhancement in the apparent dynein-dynactin inter-action at plus ends (see Fig. 3 H).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Although this effect appears to be minor compared with that of Num1 CC on the dynein-Pac1 interaction, it is possible that, like the human adaptor proteins (e.g., BicD2 and Spindly), Num1 also plays a role in stabilizing the dynein-dynactin complex.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: If so, it may be that Num1 may further promote dynactin-mediated processivity enhancement of dynein in a manner reflective of the human adaptor proteins (McKenney et al., 2014;Schlager et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Future studies will be needed to directly test this in a reconstituted system.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Although dynactin does not activate yeast dynein motility, per se, it is interesting to note that dynein-dynactin binding is a rate-limiting step during the dynein offloading process.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Quantitative fluorescence microscopy revealed a threefold excess of dynein relative to dynein-dynactin complexes at microtubule plus ends .
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Given the reliance of dynein on dynactin for offloading to Num1 receptor sites (Lee et al., 2003), the limiting nature of dynactin at plus ends effectively restricts dynein pathway activity by limiting the number of cortical dynein-dynactin complexes.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Increasing the number of intact dynein-dynactin complexes at plus ends by deletion of She1, which regulates their interaction in vivo (Woodruff et al., 2009), results in an increased number of cortical dynein-dynactin complexes, as well as enhanced dynein pathway activity .
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Thus, through mechanistically distinct processes, dynactin effectively activates dynein-mediated processes both in animal and yeast cells.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is well established that Pac1 plays a central role in targeting dynein-dynactin to microtubule plus ends in yeast (Lee Figure 7.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.section: Discussion
Discussion

body_text.text: Given the ability of Pac1 to reduce dynein motility in vitro Huang et al., 2012), it has been postulated that Pac1 may hold dynein at plus ends in part by preventing its minus end-directed motility.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: At some point after or concomitant with dynein offloading, Pac1 dissociates from dynein and is never observed at cortical Num1 sites in wild-type cells (Lee et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Given the observations presented here, we hypothesize that Num1 binding to dynein-dynactin triggers the dissociation of Pac1 from dynein.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The fact that Dyn1 ΔMT BD is insensitive to Num1 CC overexpression suggests that microtubule binding by dynein is a requisite for Pac1 dissociation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This suggests a mechanism whereby Num1 binding to the dynein tail domain (Markus et al., 2009) communicates allosteric changes to the motor head that, after microtubule binding, induce Pac1 dissociation from its binding site (at the junction between AAA3 and AAA4; Toropova et al., 2014) and consequently permit minus end-directed motility (see Fig. 8).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The requisite microtubule binding by dynein for Num1 CC -mediated Pac1 dissociation likely explains the plus end colocalization of Dyn1 ΔMT BD with Num1 CC (Fig. S5, A-C) and Pac1 (not depicted).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is interesting to note the apparent discrepancies between the requirements for plus end binding of yeast and human dynein.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In budding yeast, the dynein motor domain, Pac1, and Bik1 are absolutely essential (Lee et al., 2003;Sheeman et al., 2003;Markus et al., 2009), but dynactin is dispensable for this process (Lee et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, recent in vitro reconstitution experiments with human dynein revealed a distinct plus end binding complex that requires EB1, the p150Glued subunit of dynactin, and the full-length dynein complex (i.e., the motor domain is not sufficient; Duellberg et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These latter observations, which did not describe any minus end-directed dynein motility, suggest that dynein and dynactin (or at least p150Glued) can interact at plus ends in the absence of the recently characterized adaptor proteins (e.g., Hook3, Spindly, and BicD2;McKenney et al., 2014;Schlager et al., 2014) and further suggest that their interaction is not sufficient for dynein motility.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our observation that the MTBD of dynein is dispensable for plus end targeting was surprising and changes our understanding by which dynein recognizes and binds to microtubule plus ends.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In light of this observation, we propose that dynein does not directly contact the plus end; rather, dynein associates with plus ends indirectly through its interactions with Pac1 and Bik1 (see Fig. 1 B).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Evidence indicates that Pac1 enables dynein tip tracking in part by linking it to the plus end binding protein Bik1 (Sheeman et al., 2003;Roberts et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Thus, the ability of Pac1 (and LIS1) to permit prolonged encounters between dynein and microtubules (McKenney et al., 2010;Huang et al., 2012) is likely unrelated to plus end binding by dynein in this organism.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, it is conceivable that by maintaining dynein in an off state at plus ends, Pac1 may prevent minus end motility of dynein motors that are in very close proximity to the microtubule.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Upon binding of Num1 CC , dynein may pivot (likely in a stochastic manner) such that it may contact the plus end directly through its MTBD, subsequently release Pac1, and then walk toward the minus end.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: An analogous situation may take place in wild-type cells: after offloading to Num1 receptor sites at the cortex, dynein is well positioned to contact the microtubule to initiate spindle movements, which in turn may trigger Pac1 dissociation (Fig. 8).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Recent structural studies support such a possibility: upon microtubule binding, conformational changes within the MTBD affect corresponding changes within the motor ring (Schmidt, 2015;Uchimura et al., 2015).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These changes, which are propagated by the antiparallel coiled-coil that lead from the MTBD to the motor ring (via AAA4), could presumably affect Pac1 binding at the AAA3-AAA4 junction (see Fig. 8; Toropova et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Consistent with Num1 affecting the dynein-Pac1 interaction, the dynein mutant with higher than normal affinity for Pac1 (Dyn1 HL3 ) was much less susceptible to Num1 CC -mediated plus end depletion.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is unclear why Dyn1 HL3 exhibits higher affinity for Pac1.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This mutant was engineered such that a helical linker was inserted between the tail and motor domains Figure 8.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Model for Num1-mediated activation of dynein-mediated spindle positioning.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our data suggest that at the moment of offloading (step 1), contact between dyneindynactin and cortical Num1 triggers a cascade of events that ultimately leads to Pac1 dissociation (step 3); however, the MTBD (deletion of which interrupts this process) is required to make contact with the microtubule to initiate Pac1 dissociation (step 2).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: . In the context of the tertiary structure of the dynein motor, this region lies in close proximity to the Pac1 binding site (between AAA3 and AAA4; see Fig. 5 A). Taken together with an apparent enhanced affinity of a tail-less dynein construct (motor domain only) for Pac1 (Reck-Peterson et al., 2006;Markus et al., 2009), it stands to reason that the tail domain plays a negative regulatory role in affecting Pac1 binding. Thus, whatever allosteric conformational change Num1 CCdynein tail binding induces is likely interrupted by insertion of the helical HL3 linker.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The nature of the Num1 CC -dynein-dynactin interaction is currently unknown; however, a recent structural study revealed how human dynein-dynactin interacts with the coiled-coilcontaining adaptor protein BicD2 (Urnavicius et al., 2015).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Given the importance of the Num1 coiled-coil domain in the dynein-dynactin interaction, and the observation that Num1 (like BicD2) only interacts with intact dynein-dynactin complexes (Splinter et al., 2012), it may be that Num1 exhibits a similar mode of binding (i.e., direct contact with the dynein tail domain, and the Arp1 filament).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Future high-resolution structural studies of the dynein tail domain within the context of the Num1 CC -dynein-dynactin complex will be necessary to understand the network of interactions that define this enormous protein complex, as well as how the tail domain may possibly affect Pac1-motor domain binding.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: All strains are derived from YEF473A (Bi and Pringle, 1996) and are listed in Table S1.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: We transformed yeast strains using the lithium acetate method (Knop et al., 1999).
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: Strains carrying null mutations or fluorescently tagged components were constructed by PCR product-mediated transformation (Longtine et al., 1998) or by mating followed by tetrad dissection.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: Strains expressing mTurquoise2-Tub1 were generated as described (Markus et al., 2015).
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: Transformants were clonally purified by streaking to individual colonies on selective media.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: Proper tagging was confirmed by PCR and, in some cases, sequencing.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: Yeast synthetic defined (SD) media were obtained from Sunrise Science Products.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: To generate a yeast strain with point mutations in Num1 CC (L167E L170E; Fig. 2 A), we used the site-specific genomic mutagenesis approach (Gray et al., 2004).
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: In brief, after integration of the URA3 cassette into the num1 CC locus (replacing nucleotides 499-510, corresponding to amino acids L167-L170), a PCR product amplified from pSM37 (see Plasmid construction) containing the desired nucleotide substitutions was transformed into the URA3-integrated strain and subsequently selected on 5-fluoroorotic acid-containing plates.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: 5-Fluoroorotic acid-resistant colonies were selected and confirmed by colony PCR and sequencing of the genomic DNA region.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: A similar method was used to delete the MTBD (residues 3,102-3,225) from DYN1.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: To generate a yeast strain expressing the GAL1p:PH-DYN1 allele, a cassette containing KAN R ::GAL1p:PH was amplified from pFA6a-kanMX6-pGAL1-PH (see Plasmid construction) and used for integration immediately upstream of the DYN1-3mCherry locus.
body_text.section: Media and strain construction

body_text.text: Using isothermal assembly (Gibson et al., 2009), we generated a plasmid in which the L167E L170E point mutations were engineered into a plasmid encoding Num1 CC(95-303) -PCN-S-TEV-ZZ (pBSG02; Tang et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: In brief, primers were used to separately amplify the N-terminal (nucleotides 283-498, corresponding to amino acids 95-166) and C-terminal (nucleotides 511-909, corresponding to amino acids 171-303) portions of Num1 CC , such that the desired nucleotide substitutions were included in the reverse primer for the N-terminal portion and the forward primer for the C-terminal portion.
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: After amplification, the 3′ and 5′ ends of the PCR products corresponding to the N-and C-terminal regions, respectively, contained 20 nucleotides of sequence identity with each other, whereas the 5′ and 3′ ends of the N-and C-terminal regions, respectively, contained 20 nucleotides of sequence identity with the NcoI-and NotI-digested pBSG02 vector.
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: After digesting pBSG02 with NcoI and NotI (to excise Num1 CC(95-303) wild type), the gelpurified PCR products and digested vector were assembled in vitro as described (Gibson et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: Proper assembly was verified by restriction digest and DNA sequencing and resulted in pSM37 (encoding Num1 CC(95-303) LL/EE -PCN-S-TEV-ZZ).
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: To generate a plasmid with which to N-terminally tag Dyn1 with a PH domain, the PH domain of Num1 (amino acids 2,563-2,692) was amplified using a forward primer flanked with an XmaI site and a reverse primer flanked with a SalI site.
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: The PCR product was digested with XmaI and SalI and ligated into pFA6a-kanMX6-PGAL1 (Longtine et al., 1998) digested similarly, yielding pFA6a-kanMX6-PGAL1-PH.
body_text.section: Plasmid construction

body_text.text: Yeast cultures were imaged after growth at 30°C to mid-log phase in synthetic defined media supplemented with either 2% glucose (SD plus glucose) or 2% galactose plus 2% raffinose (SD plus galactose/ raffinose; the latter for induction of Num1 CC , Pac1, or Kip2, as indicated).
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: To assess the effects of Num1 CC on localization of dynein pathway components, GAL1p:num1 CC cells were induced in SD plus galactose/raffinose for 6 h before mounting cells for fluorescence microscopy.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: For wide-field fluorescence microscopy, yeast cells were imaged on an agarose pad containing 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7, and images were collected at room temperature using a 1.49 NA 100× objective on a Ti-E inverted microscope equipped with a Ti-S-E motorized stage (Nikon), piezo Z-control (Physik Instrumente), a SOLA SM II LE LED light engine (Lumencor), a motorized filter cube turret, and an iXon X3 DU897 cooled EM-CCD camera (Andor).
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: The microscope system was controlled by NIS-Elements software (Nikon).
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: A step size of 1 µm was used to acquire 2-µm-thick Z-stack images.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Sputtered/ET filter cube sets (Chroma Technology) were used for imaging mTurquoise2 (49001), GFP (49002), YFP (49003), and mCherry (49008) fluorescence.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Image analysis was performed using ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health; kymographs in Fig. 7 were generated with the MultipleKymograph plugin).
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Plus end and SPB foci were identified in two (or three) color movies and scored accordingly.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Specifically, plus end molecules were recognized as those foci that localized to the distal tips of dynamic microtubules (identified via mTurquoise2-Tub1 imaging), whereas SPB molecules were recognized as those foci that localized to one of the spindle poles.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Cortical molecules (e.g., in PH-Dyn1-expressing cells) were identified as those foci not associated with an astral microtubule plus end that remained stationary at the cell cortex for at least three frames.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Two data sets were considered statistically significant if a Student's t test (assuming unequal variance) returned a p-value < 0.05.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: For highly inclined and laminated optical sheet microscopy (Tokunaga et al., 2008), samples were prepared and imaged as above, except 488-and 561-nm lasers were used to excite YFP and mCherry, respectively.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: The laser illumination angle was adjusted individually for each sample to achieve the maximum signal-to-noise ratio.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: Emission filters were 525/50 nm for YFP and 600/50 for mCherry.
body_text.section: Image acquisition, analysis, and dynein motility assay

body_text.text: For Western blotting, yeast cultures were grown at 30°C in 3 ml of either SD plus glucose or SD plus galactose/raffinose and harvested.

body_text.section: Cell lysis and immunoblotting

body_text.text: After centrifugation, the resulting cell pellet was resuspended in sample buffer and heated to ∼100°C for 3 min.
body_text.section: Cell lysis and immunoblotting

body_text.text: Lysates were separated on a 10% SDS polyacrylamide gel and electroblotted to PVDF in 25 mM Tris and 192 mM glycine supplemented with 0.05% SDS and 10% methanol for 30 min.
body_text.section: Cell lysis and immunoblotting
